headline.main: Other Business; NEW MAN, OLD PATCH

results.snippet: He has returned. The same, yet different. Mysterious, but gentler.  Authoritative, but a family man. He is the man with the eyepatch - the man in the Hathaway shirt ad. ''A man's man,'' explains Hathaway's vice president of marketing, Albert J....
results.lead_paragraph: He has returned. The same, yet different. Mysterious, but gentler. Authoritative, but a family man. He is the man with the eyepatch - the man in the Hathaway shirt ad. ''A man's man,'' explains Hathaway's vice president of marketing, Albert J. DiMarco.

headline.main: NEW-WAVE ROCK: DEVO FROM OHIO

results.snippet: wave quintet from Akron, Ohio, are media satirists whose theatricality is at least as important as their music. The group, whose premise is that the human race is in a process of ''devolution,'' actually markets its fashions, which include rubber...
results.lead_paragraph: wave quintet from Akron, Ohio, are media satirists whose theatricality is at least as important as their music. The group, whose premise is that the human race is in a process of ''devolution,'' actually markets its fashions, which include rubber pompadour hairpieces in red and black, quasi-astronaut uniforms, 3-D glasses and ''energy dome'' hats.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS ARRIVE AT CAPE AS COUNTDOWN ADVANCES SMOOTHLY

results.snippet: The astronauts who will pilot the space shuttle Columbia for its second mission arrived here this afternoon as countdown preparations continued at a leisurely pace surprisingly free of glitches and gremlins.   Col. Joe H. Engle of the Air Force and...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The astronauts who will pilot the space shuttle Columbia for its second mission arrived here this afternoon as countdown preparations continued at a leisurely pace surprisingly free of glitches and gremlins. Col. Joe H. Engle of the Air Force and Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy flew T-38 jet trainers from the Johnson Space Center at Houston to Patrick Air Force Base near here. They landed at 2:45 P.M., made brief statements about the Columbia being ready and ''the greatest'' and went to the Kennedy Space Center for final briefings and relaxation. ''We're mighty glad we're getting this close to flying,'' said Colonel Engle, the mission commander. The mission was originally scheduled for a Sept. 30 launching, then reset for Oct. 9 and postponed again because of a propellant spill that damaged the outer surface of the Columbia's forward fuselage.

headline.main: EJECTION FROM SPACE SHUTTLE ON GROUND COULD BE PERILOUS

results.snippet: Nobody has ever pulled the D ring, and space agency officials frankly fear the consequences if Col. Joe H. Engle of the Air Force and Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy must eject from the Columbia in the event of an accident on the launching pad. ...
results.lead_paragraph: Nobody has ever pulled the D ring, and space agency officials frankly fear the consequences if Col. Joe H. Engle of the Air Force and Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy must eject from the Columbia in the event of an accident on the launching pad. The space shuttle's ejection seats, similar to those used successfully for pilots flying high-performance aircraft, would be far more useful should there be an emergency in the Columbia's approach for landing, according to officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Once activated, and only in dire emergency, the D-shaped-ring positioned between the astronauts' legs detonates explosive devices that catapult the crew from their seats through escape panels in the cockpit ceiling. They would be sent spinning away from the spacecraft, with parachutes opening to ease their escape descent.

headline.main: Quotation of the Day

results.snippet: ''You bet your life we are ready. Everything's looking beautiful.'' -Col. Joe H. Engle, space shuttle astronaut.
results.lead_paragraph: ''You bet your life we are ready. Everything's looking beautiful.'' -Col. Joe H. Engle, space shuttle astronaut.

headline.main: TROUBLE-FREE PREPARATIONS ELATE CREW FOR 2D SHUTTLE FLIGHT TODAY

results.snippet: The second flight of the shuttle Columbia is about to mark the first critical test of the reuse of a spaceship for scores of trips to and from the orbital frontier.   Today's launching, scheduled for 7:30 A.M., is the first attempt to fly a used...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The second flight of the shuttle Columbia is about to mark the first critical test of the reuse of a spaceship for scores of trips to and from the orbital frontier. Today's launching, scheduled for 7:30 A.M., is the first attempt to fly a used spaceship. The United States has invested at least $10 billion so far to develop the Columbia as a vehicle capable of perhaps 100 round trips to space, and, depending on its success in early test flights, a fleet of four shuttles is expected to be in operation by the middle of the decade. The planned five-day mission, to be flown by Col. Joe H. Engle of the Air Force and Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy, will be marked by the first working payload of scientific instruments to be carried by the 122-foot-long winged spaceplane and extensive testing of the vehicle's 50-foot robot arm for handling cargoes.

headline.main: FAMILY AFFAIRS

results.snippet: TRIPLETS By Joyce Rebeta-Burditt.  495 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $15.95. MAZES AND MONSTERS By Rona Jaffe.  329 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $13.95.   IF art is, among other things, a spiritual survival manual for its times,...

byline.original: By ANNIE GOTTLIEB; Annie Gottlieb is a freelance writer anc critic

results.lead_paragraph: TRIPLETS By Joyce Rebeta-Burditt. 495 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $15.95. MAZES AND MONSTERS By Rona Jaffe. 329 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $13.95. IF art is, among other things, a spiritual survival manual for its times, then new styles of art are inventive responses to new problems of survival. The problem we face right now is how to find and hold a center of human meaning in a world where values and institutions are not just falling but flying apart. It seems to me that a new style of popular art has appeared to instruct us, exemplified in the dramatic media by television's superb ''Hill Street Blues'' and in fiction by Joyce Rebeta-Burditt's second novel, ''Triplets.''

headline.main: AMID JOY AT LAUNCHING, WHISPERS OF DOUBT RISE

results.snippet: The lapidary work done, as if on a damaged diamond, the first secondhand rose of America's space age got aloft at last today. Time - overtime, rather, at a cost of between $1.5 million and $2 million for the latest delay -and tinkering made for a...

byline.original: By GREGORY JAYNES, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The lapidary work done, as if on a damaged diamond, the first secondhand rose of America's space age got aloft at last today. Time - overtime, rather, at a cost of between $1.5 million and $2 million for the latest delay -and tinkering made for a momentous encore of the space shuttle Columbia. There was only a small audience, although the fire and groundshaking thunder were no less impressive than in April, when close to a million people crowded round to see the maiden flight. Local law-enforcement officials estimated that fewer than 100,000 people came out this time, and most of them were in vans with Florida tags. The reason for the low number, local residents reckoned, was either fear of another postponement, or ennui.

headline.main: ENGLE: FROM CHILDHOOD HE PLANNED TO BE A PILOT

results.snippet: Rarely, if ever, does Col. Joe Henry Engle of the Air Force show any sign of becoming satiated with flying, any kind of flying.  He has flown 135 kinds of aircraft in his more than two decades as a pilot, logging more than 8,350 hours of flight...
results.lead_paragraph: Rarely, if ever, does Col. Joe Henry Engle of the Air Force show any sign of becoming satiated with flying, any kind of flying. He has flown 135 kinds of aircraft in his more than two decades as a pilot, logging more than 8,350 hours of flight time, of which 6,000 hours was in jets. He has piloted some of the most sophisticated equipment this country has produced, including the X-15 research rocket plane early in the 1960's. Yesterday he took off in the space shuttle Columbia. Through it all, he has retained an affection for the relatively unsophisticated airplanes used when he was growing up in World War II. He is especially fascinated with the Curtiss P-40, which he has flown. It was widely used by the command of Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault in the war over China and Burma, where the Japanese lost 299 planes in seven months. Planes captured his imagination and he once said, ''I can't remember when I didn't want to fly airplanes and be a fighter pilot.''

headline.main: TRULY: GRANDFATHER, 44, HAS A BIRTHDAY IN SPACE

results.snippet: Capt. Richard Harrison Truly of the Navy yesterday became the first grandfather, so far as is known in this country, to enter space. And he is a young grandfather: Because of previous delays in the second flight of the space shuttle Columbia,...
results.lead_paragraph: Capt. Richard Harrison Truly of the Navy yesterday became the first grandfather, so far as is known in this country, to enter space. And he is a young grandfather: Because of previous delays in the second flight of the space shuttle Columbia, Captain Truly's liftoff occurred on his 44th birthday. Though Captain Truly has won more than his share of medals and citations as a pilot and astronaut, flying has not always been an all-consuming passion, as it has for Col. Joe H. Engle of the Air Force, his shuttle partner. ''He had no particular aspirations to become a pilot when he was a boy,'' said his father, James B. Truly, who is a retired lawyer for the Federal Trade Commission. His son agrees.

headline.main: News Summary; FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1981

results.snippet: International The aims of American foreign policy were reviewed by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in Congressional testimony. He said the Reagan Administration sought to encourage constructive relations with Moscow while renewing...
results.lead_paragraph: International The aims of American foreign policy were reviewed by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in Congressional testimony. He said the Reagan Administration sought to encourage constructive relations with Moscow while renewing traditional alliances, restoring American economic and military strength and promoting peaceful development in the third world. During questioning, Mr. Haig refused to rule out a possible blockade of Nicaragua. (Page A1, Column 3.) Exxon is withdrawing from Libya after 26 years of pumping crude oil there. Spokesmen for Exxon, the largest American oil company, declined repeated requests to explain whether the decision was taken because of a dispute with Libya over oil production or prices or because of political or security reasons. (A1:2-4.)

headline.main: FAILURE OF A POWER DEVICE LED TO A FEAR OF EXPLOSION

results.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia was betrayed today by a piece of equipment that has been standard on almost every manned space flight made by Americans during the last 16 years. It is the fuel cell, which, through the chemical reaction of oxygen and...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia was betrayed today by a piece of equipment that has been standard on almost every manned space flight made by Americans during the last 16 years. It is the fuel cell, which, through the chemical reaction of oxygen and hydrogen, produces all electrical power for the spacecraft. It is as familiar and mundane a fixture to an astronaut as an automobile battery is to a motorist. And until today, none had ever failed with major consequences. This time, it forced mission controllers to consider reducing the duration of Columbia's second flight, perhaps by as much as half.

headline.main: CRAFT'S MECHANICAL ARM FACES FIRST TEST IN SPACE

results.snippet: A 50-foot, many-jointed mechanical arm aboard the Columbia is to unlimber itself tomorrow morning under astronaut control. It will then reach out into the void in the first test of a device on which the space shuttle's future usefulness depends.  ...

byline.original: By WALTER SULLIVAN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A 50-foot, many-jointed mechanical arm aboard the Columbia is to unlimber itself tomorrow morning under astronaut control. It will then reach out into the void in the first test of a device on which the space shuttle's future usefulness depends. Only by means of this arm, comparable to two telephone poles end to end, will the shuttle be able to lift various payloads from the cargo bay and place them in orbit. It will also provide the only means for retrieving satellites or their payloads, including photographic film, for return to the earth.

headline.main: CONTROL TO CREW: GOOD AND BAD NEWS

results.snippet: Following are excerpts from converstations the astronauts had with Mission Control in Houston on the second day of the space shuttle's flight, as recorded by The New York Times and The Associated Press.  ''Sally'' is Dr. Sally Ride, an astronaut...
results.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from converstations the astronauts had with Mission Control in Houston on the second day of the space shuttle's flight, as recorded by The New York Times and The Associated Press. ''Sally'' is Dr. Sally Ride, an astronaut who served yesterday as capsule communicator. COLUMBIA: Houston, Columbia. HOUSTON: Go ahead. COLUMBIA: Roger. Are you getting TV down there? HOUSTON: We had a great picture of the flag from Camera Delta, and now we've got a test pattern. COLUMBIA: O.K. If you get a chance during the pass, want you to get in talk to look at the R.M.S. elbow camera and tell us when you can do that if you get it locked up.

headline.kicker: ASTRONAUTS ORDERED TO END FLIGHT TODAY, 3 DAYS EARLY
headline.main: RECALL 'PRUDENT,' NASA SAYS

results.snippet: The astronauts flying the space shuttle Columbia were ordered today to cut short their mission and prepare to bring the troubled craft back to a landing tomorrow afternoon in the desert of California.   Col. Joe H. Engle of the Air Force and Capt....

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The astronauts flying the space shuttle Columbia were ordered today to cut short their mission and prepare to bring the troubled craft back to a landing tomorrow afternoon in the desert of California. Col. Joe H. Engle of the Air Force and Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy plan to steer the winged spaceship to a touchdown at 4:22 P.M., Eastern standard time. Until one of the craft's three fuel cells failed after liftoff yesterday, the mission was supposed to last five days, ending next Tuesday. Now it is scheduled to end after two days, six hours and 12 minutes. 'Prudent Thing to Do' Christopher C. Kraft Jr., director of the Johnson Space Center here, said at a news conference this afternoon that the decision to curtail the flight was ''the prudent thing to do at this point'' in testing the world's first re-usable space vehicle.

headline.main: GUSTY WINDS CAUSE A LAST-MINUTE REASSIGNMENT OF RUNWAY FOR THE SHUTTLE

results.snippet: A rapid freshening of the wind from the southwest, with gusts to 28 miles per hour, led to a last-minute reassignment of the runway for today's landing of the space shuttle Columbia.   The choice of runways had presented the space agency with a...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A rapid freshening of the wind from the southwest, with gusts to 28 miles per hour, led to a last-minute reassignment of the runway for today's landing of the space shuttle Columbia. The choice of runways had presented the space agency with a difficult decision. One runway, No. 15, offered a chance to test the shuttle's ability in a crosswind, considered an important examination of how it would deal with stresses it had not yet encountered. The other runway, No. 23, would confront the shuttle with headwinds only. But it was the one prepared with the new electronic landing system that also needed further testing.

headline.kicker: SPACE SHUTTLE LANDS SAFELY AFTER ITS TROUBLED MISSION
headline.main: MOST OF ITS TESTS COMPLETED

results.snippet: The shortened flight of the space shuttle Columbia came to a safe conclusion here today as two American astronauts steered the winged spaceship through cloudy skies and stiff winds to a graceful touchdown.   Col. Joe H. Engle of the Air Force and...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The shortened flight of the space shuttle Columbia came to a safe conclusion here today as two American astronauts steered the winged spaceship through cloudy skies and stiff winds to a graceful touchdown. Col. Joe H. Engle of the Air Force and Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy brought the Columbia, the first used vehicle to orbit the earth, to a landing at 4:23 P.M., Eastern standard time, disappointed that they had been unable to complete the full five-day mission. The failure of one of the craft's three fuel cells forced them to come home after only 54 hours and 36 revolutions of the earth. As the Columbia soared into sight over the Mojave Desert, announcing itself with thudding sonic booms, tens of thousands of people peered upward from the perimeter of the Rogers Dry Lake landing site. They cheered as the glistening white craft glided over the desert, made a wide sweeping turn and put down on the hard desert floor.

headline.main: HOUSTON AND COLUMBIA: TALK ON THE WAY HOME

results.snippet: Following are excerpts from conversations the astronauts had with Mission Control in Houston on the third and last day of the space shuttle's flight, as recorded by The New York Times. ''Rick'' is Comdr. Frederick H. Hauck of the Navy, an...
results.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from conversations the astronauts had with Mission Control in Houston on the third and last day of the space shuttle's flight, as recorded by The New York Times. ''Rick'' is Comdr. Frederick H. Hauck of the Navy, an astronaut, navy aviator and test pilot, who served as capsule communicator yesterday. Shuttle Control is the public affairs commentary of Mission Control. HOUSTON: This is Shuttle Control. The crew will be conducting the flight control system checkout over this pass over the United States, in preparation for entering. Clock counting down now five hours, 30 minutes to ignition.

headline.main: A Cram Course For Columbia

results.snippet: It was a beautiful liftoff; ''picture perfect,'' observers exclaimed as the space shuttle Columbia, for the second time, climbed into the bright blue Florida sky last week. Even astronaut Richard H. Truly, a Navy captain who happened to be...
results.lead_paragraph: It was a beautiful liftoff; ''picture perfect,'' observers exclaimed as the space shuttle Columbia, for the second time, climbed into the bright blue Florida sky last week. Even astronaut Richard H. Truly, a Navy captain who happened to be celebrating his 44th birthday, remarked ''We've really been having a lot of fun.'' Not for long. About an hour into the flight, one of Columbia's three fuel cells signaled abnormal temperature and acid levels. The trouble persisted, forcing shutdown of the obdurate equipment and, as safety rules dictate, curtailment of the mission to ''the minimum'' - 54 hours, or 36 orbits, instead of the originally scheduled 124 hour, or 83-orbit flight.

headline.main: Ex-Astronaut Says He's Not Envious

results.snippet: Wally Schirra, one of the seven original astronauts, said yesterday that he was glad to be resting comfortably on Earth instead of orbiting the planet aboard the Columbia.   ''I'm grateful I'm not there,'' he said, ''mostly because sitting out...
results.lead_paragraph: Wally Schirra, one of the seven original astronauts, said yesterday that he was glad to be resting comfortably on Earth instead of orbiting the planet aboard the Columbia. ''I'm grateful I'm not there,'' he said, ''mostly because sitting out there can become boring as hell.''

headline.main: SHUTTLE WEATHERS ITS SECOND MISSION WITH LESS DAMAGE

results.snippet: After a preliminary inspection, space agency officials said today that the space shuttle Columbia suffered ''considerably less'' visible wear and tear on its second flight than on its first. They said it should be ready for another trip in March.  ...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WIlFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: After a preliminary inspection, space agency officials said today that the space shuttle Columbia suffered ''considerably less'' visible wear and tear on its second flight than on its first. They said it should be ready for another trip in March. Only 12 of the craft's 31,000 heat-protective tiles were known to be damaged and to require replacement, compared with 164 tiles that were ripped off or damaged in the Columbia's first flight last April, presumably because there was not so much pressure at liftoff, employees said. Donald K. Slayton, the astronaut who is manager of the orbital test program, said at a news conference here that the winged spaceship ''looks superb, looks considerably better than after the first flight, with considerably less damage.''

headline.main: Miami's Leaders Join To Fight Crime Rate

results.snippet: Officials of the Chamber of Commerce, awaiting tourists fleeing winter's snow and slush, have designed a new plan to fight increasing crime in Miami.   A 50-member Action Committee on Crime is to meet weekly to work out specific ways for the city's...
results.lead_paragraph: Officials of the Chamber of Commerce, awaiting tourists fleeing winter's snow and slush, have designed a new plan to fight increasing crime in Miami. A 50-member Action Committee on Crime is to meet weekly to work out specific ways for the city's business community to help, according to Walter Revell, the chamber's president.
